titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Called at Mr: Boyd’s this morning with a letter from Caroline to Eliza Johnson— Heard Mr: Laurie at the Treasury— Met Mr: Hopkinson and Mr Hare of Philadelphia— Dined at Mr: Boyd’s— Mr: Ripley and Mr: Brimmer from Boston were there after dinner— Evening at home, writing in my chamber.

2. Very little business done in Senate this day— My Resolution for adopting a new Rule for conducting business in Senate, was referr’d to a select Committee— Mr: Giles, Mr: Tracy and myself— Several Messages were received from the President; and before 12. A Message from the House of Representatives communicating information of the Death of General Levi Casey, a member of that House from South-Carolina; and that the funeral was to be this day at 1. O’Clock. The Senate immediately resolved to attend the funeral; and according to custom in such cases, adjourn’d— By invitation of Mr: Giles I took a seat with him in his Carriage— Dr: Mitchill, and Mr: Milledge also went with him— It was however past 3. before we left the Capitol, and about 5 when the procession left reached the Georgetown Bridge— I then left them, and came home— The Vice-President conversed much with me on the subject of Mr: Burr, of whom he spoke in terms of great indignation— Mr: Giles mentioned the transactions in Senate last Session respecting Mr: Eaton, with approbation.

3. The Committee on my proposed new Rule were to have met this morning; but Mr: Giles was prevented from attending by the illness of a child— The Senate were engaged almost the whole day through, with a Bill to prevent unauthorized Settlements on Lands ceded to the United States— An Anti-Yazoo project— The bill was finally recommitted to a select Committee— I met Mr: Gilman and Mr: Tracy, upon the Bill for the relief of the Portsmouth sufferers by fire; and we agreed that it should be reported without Amendment.— Evening in my chamber, chiefly employed in arranging papers.

4. On going to the Senate this morning Dr: Mitchill introduced to me Mr: Rifford, whom I had often seen at Cambridge last Summer, and who is here with a view to introduce his method of teaching to write— I attended the Committee on my proposed new Rule, and Mr: Giles proposed an Amendment to which I assented— It was reported, and the Rule thus amended was adopted without a division— The Columbia District fee-bill was read the third time— Mr: Bradley still persisted in his opposition; but the Bill passed by a large Majority— Another bill also pass’d; and several others were partly considered. The new bill respecting the funds was taken up for consideration, and read through without remark— As the question was about to be taken, I asked for its postponement for the purpose of proposing an amendment— This motion was opposed by Mr: Giles and Mr: Bradley— I finally moved to adjourn; which motion succeeded— In Executive business some nominations were approved. I passed the Evening in my chamber; assorting and arranging papers—reading & writing.

5. Attended the Committee on the Bill to punish counterfeiting of bank Notes U.S— Report not definitively agreed upon. The bill respecting the public funds pass’d to the third reading, notwithstanding some objections from Mr: Hillhouse— I offered a Resolution for the appointment of a joint Committee, to enquire and report on the Bill, which was erroneously enroll’d the last Session. it lies for consideration— The reported Resolution for granting lands to purchase stock in the Delaware and Chesapeake Canal Company was taken up, and advocated much at length by Mr: Bayard— Some opposition was made by Mr: Giles, (who voted however for the Resolution) by Mr: Baldwin, and by me— It was adopted however by a large Majority, and a Committee appointed to bring in a Bill— In the Evening, the Ladies went to the Ball— I employed it at home writing, and arranging papers— I this morning finished reading what is called Homer’s Hymn to Apollo; and began the hymn to Mercury— They are written in imitation of Homer’s style; and several of his verses are introduced in them— But they have none of his majestic ideas, and none of his fertility of Imagination— The Hymn to Apollo contains upwards of 500 lines, and contain a history of that God’s birth and some of his adventures— Especially the establishment of his temple at Delphi— There are some graceful and elegant images in it; but neither the fire nor the profusion of thought remarkable in Homer.—

6. I had some difficulty in getting to and from the Capitol, owing to the violence of the wind, and the severity of the cold— Both houses were obliged to adjourn at an early hour; their windows having been blown in— The Senate however had gone through all the business before them— The new funding system Act pass’d— The Resolution I offer’d yesterday was at the request of Mr: Bradley, referr’d to a select Committee—Mr: Bradley—Mr Giles and myself— I spent the Evening in my chamber; but the cold was so great that I wasted the time in Idleness.

7. The weather last Night, and through the whole of this day has been more severely cold than I have ever known it at this place— My thermometer stood last night at 3 degrees, and this morning at only 2. above 0.— And I was not up untill after the Sun. I confined myself to my chamber, and spent the whole day, and almost all the Evening, in a very idle amusement— Even in writing verses— I wrote however a little upon my unfinished lecture in the Evening— I had not a tedious hour in the day.

8. I finished reading this morning Homer’s Hymn to Hermes, and began that to Venus— The first gives an account of the God’s birth, and how on the same day he was born, and stole the oxen or rather cows of Apollo, and his ingenious device to hide them.— The accusation of Apollo; his defence—the trial of the Cause before Jupiter, who acquits Hermes— His subsequent avowal of the fact, and his compact of Friendship with Apollo— His invention of the lyre, from a tortoise shell is also related; and how the office of messenger to the Gods was finally given him by Jupiter— Homer (or rather the author) makes him from the instant of his birth a most impudent thief, and a most intrepid liar— It seems to be from the same hand as the hymn to Apollo.— I went with Catherine & Eliza Johnson to Mr: Boyd’s— Heard Mr: Laurie at the Treasury— I dined at Mr: Boyd’s, and spent the Evening principally there— Mr: Walter Boyd was there at dinner. Mr: Ripley afterwards— I received this morning from W. S. Shaw Selfridge’s trial— The whole time I had through the day I was engaged in reading it, and did not get through it untill after midnight—

9. The weather has at length moderated, and the wind changed to the South— The business in Senate was dispatched as has been usual during the present Session almost without debate— Evening in my chamber— I finished reading Homer’s Hymn to Venus, which principally consists of the Story of her amour with Anchises— It is more Homeric than the preceding hymns.

10. The business in Senate is transacted, with a degree of indifference and carelessness which I never witness’d in any public assembly before— Bill after Bill passes without any remark; and even without explanation of its subject— The only appearance of a debate this day was upon a Bill reported by Mr: Bayard, for selling land to the Delaware and Schuylkill Canal Company for Shares in their Stock— I objected against its passage to the second reading, as being a Bill to raise Revenue; but without any effect— Senate adjourned about 2. O’Clock— I attended a short time in the Supreme Court; and afterwards called at the House of Representatives; where they were warmly debating the Slave Bill which went from the Senate— A letter to the President, from Cowles Mead Secretary of the Mississippi Territory, was communicated by message to Congress— It was dated 13. Jany: and mentions a letter then just received from Mr: Burr—declaring a pacific purpose; but intimating a determination to resist, if an attempt should be made to take him, and deprecating a civil War— I spent the Evening again at home— But idly.

11. In Senate— The Bill to prevent settlements on lands ceded to the United States, unless authorized by law, after an animated debate pass’d by a bare majority 17 to 15. Several attempts were previously made for its commitment; for postponement, and for adjournment, which were all rejected by the same majority— I took little part in the debate; but specifically objected against the principle of forfeiting title to land, for acts less than Treason, the Constitution having expressly provided against such forfeiture, for Treason itself.— Adjourned immediately after the question taken— Evening again at home; and again idle—

12. The Vice-President this morning took me apart, and advised me to ask leave to bring in a bill in behalf of the Yazoo claimants, like that which pass’d the Senate, at the last Session, to remove the effect of the Bill pass’d yesterday— But I do not think it would answer any such purpose— I met Genl: Smith and Mr: Bradley on the Committee respecting a proposed additional article of War— We came however to no decision— The Bill for repealing the duties on Salt &c—was again postpon’d untill Monday next— There was a very warm debate on an Amendment to a Bill establishing a sort of feudal militia in New-Orleans, which was finally rejected, after a forcible argument by Mr: Tracy— I rode to the Capitol this morning, as there was a heavy Rain, but walk’d home— Began writing some new lines, which occupied me, almost the whole Evening.

13. The rain continued all last Night, and the whole of this day— I rode to and from the Capitol— Met the Committee on the bill respecting the District of Columbia, and agreed to report the Bill without Amendment which was done, and it pass’d to the third reading— Mr: Bayard’s Bill for a grant of Land to the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal Company, was postponed untill Monday; to which day the Senate adjourn’d at an early hour— I attended in the Supreme Court, untill their adjournment; but nothing of note was before them— They decided this morning to issue the Writs of Habeas Corpus for Bollman and Swartwout, returnable on Monday. I afterwards went into the lobby of the House of Representatives, and heard Mr: Quincy on a debate respecting a Resolution to fortify New-York— The house adjourn’d, about 4. O’Clock— I was still employed this Evening in writing, and in copying, an operation which consumes much valuable Time.

14. Rain still continued all Night, and the former part of this day— River open— I was again occupied all this day, in copying, a process which in writing verses, I am obliged to repeat two or three times— Spent the Evening with the Ladies at Genl: Mason’s, Georgetown—partly at Whist—partly in conversation with Mr: J. Randolph, Dr: Jones; Captain Lewis, and Mr: Sheldon— I have been these three days unwell with a severe cold, and the rhumatism in my shoulder— The business about which I ought to be employed languishes inexcusably.

15. The weather and the badness of the Roads detained me at home, the whole of this day. Mr: Boyd dined here— Towards Evening it cleared off again and became very cold— Judge Livingston, Mr: Verplanck and General Van Cortlandt spent the Evening here.— I finished this day the last fair copy of some Stanzas entitled A Winter’s day; containing in verse a very minute and exact account of my daily occupations— I wrote also very little upon my lecture, which has been so long neglected.

16. The Vice-President did not attend in Senate this day, being indisposed; and having been up all Night with his Daughter, who is at the point of Death— Senate adjourned immediately, on the information from the Secretary that the Vice-President would not appear. I wrote to Mrs: Adams enclosing the Stanza’s, and attended in the Supreme Court where I heard part of an Argument by Mr: C. Lee, and by Mr: F. V. Key in behalf of Swartwout and Bollman, upon the return to the writ of Habeas Corpus issued by this Court— I was obliged to leave the Court before the argument was closed, being engaged to dine with the President— The Company consisted altogether of federal members of Congress— The President was less cheerful in his manners than usual; but told some of
of his customary staring Stories— Among the rest he said that before he went from Virginia to France, he had some ripe pairs sewed up in tow bags, and that when he returned six years afterwards, he found them in a perfect state of preservation; self-candied— From the President’s, I went with the Ladies, whom I met as I was returning home, to Captain Thompson’s— Here there was a numerous evening party— I spent the Evening in conversation with various gentlemen; not at all to my own satisfaction— But it preserved me from cards— We came home about 11.

17. I called at Mr: Boyd’s on my way to the Capitol this morning, and saw Eliza who is quite unwell— For the first time this Session, I left the Senate for about an hour to hear the argument on the case of Swartwout and Bollman— Mr: Jones the District Attorney was speaking; but I was called back to the Bill concerning the District of Columbia, against which at the third reading, Mr: Giles had made a sudden and unexpected attack— I defended it as well as I could; and with the aid of Messrs: Bradley and Tracy who also were of the reporting Committee, and of Genl: Smith of Maryland, who also took a part in its favour the bill pass’d; opposed by Mr: Giles alone—and without a division— The Bill for repealing the Salt duties, and continuing the Mediterranean fund was taken up, and a speech made against it by Dr: Mitchill; which brought the hour of 3. and the Senate adjourned— I then went again into Court; but they also immediately afterwards adjourned— The Ladies all attended a Ball at Mr: Erskine’s; but feeling some return again of my rhumatism I sent an excuse, and spent the Evening in my chamber— I wrote, and enclosed some lines to W. S. Shaw.

18. The salt and mediterranean fund Bill, employed in Senate the principal part of this day— It rained almost all day— I rode to the Capitol— After the adjournment I went into the House of Representatives, and heard a very warm debate upon a Resolution offered by Mr: Broom, for a Committee to enquire whether some further security ought not to be given for the writ of Habeas Corpus— The House adjourned about 4— Dined at Mr: Tayloe’s, and went with Mr: Quincy— The Company were about twenty— Gentlemen and Ladies— In the Evening there was an addition of about as many more— We had music from the Ladies; but no cards— Returning home, I took up Mrs: Johnson, at Mr: Boyd’s, where I had left her in the morning.

19. I was obliged again to ride to the Capitol—but walk’d home— Call’d as I went, at Mr: Boyd’s— The Senate received this morning a message from the President containing three important articles of intelligence— 1. A letter from the Ministers at London, announcing that they had agreed upon a Treaty with G. Britain, which would be signed in a few days— 2. A letter from Mr: Armstrong; enclosing his correspondence with the French Minister of Marine respecting the Decree to blockade the British Islands— The Minister assuring Mr: Armstrong that the Treaty between France and U.S. would be respected— And 3. A Letter from Cowles Mead Secretary, and acting as Governor of the Mississippi Territory, with information that Mr: Burr had surrendered himself his men and his boats— We had some discussion on the Salt Bill, and also on Mr: Bayard’s Bill for granting lands to the Canal Company— They were both finally postponed for further discussion to-morrow— The St: Domingo trade bill was resumed, upon which I took some papers & documents respecting the fee-bill, sent from the Senate to the House, which I delivered to Mr: Goldsborough; a member of the Committee of the House, to whom that bill is referred— I also spoke of it to Mr: Blount another member of the Committee— In the House I heard a further debate on Mr: Broom’s resolution— Mr: John Randolph spoke long; with his usual energy and bitterness— The debate was continued untill I left the house at almost 5 in the afternoon— I left Mr: Kelly speaking— In the Evening the Ladies went to the Ball— I spent it in my chamber; yet a little unwell, with rhumatism.

20. The bill for repealing the Salt duties and continuing the Mediterranean fund, pass’d to the third reading as amended in Senate— We had some debate on a point of order, and the propriety of taking over again in Senate the same questions which have already been taken as in Committee of the whole— It was the first instance since I have been in Senate that this second taking of the question had been called for, and from its disuse the right was questioned— After about an hour of confused and indistinct discussion a reference to Mr: Jefferson’s Manual, and to the Reasons, upon which our forms of proceeding are founded immediately settled the discussion; and the questions were again taken— At one taking of the yeas and nays.— Mr: Clay was absent at the call of his name, but came into his seat before the call was finished— He asked and obtained leave to have his vote taken & recorded. The bill to continue the prohibition of the St: Domingo trade pass’d— A bill, among other things extending the right of suffrage to certain inhabitants of the Mississippi Territory was taken up and warmly debated— Being a subject in which Mr: Giles’s Yazooism was roused— It was 4 O’Clock before the Senate adjourned over to Monday; leaving this as unfinished business— I dined, with
with a Company of Gentlemen at Mr: Duvall’s— Captains Lewis and Clarke were there— In the Evening there was a more numerous Company—Ladies and Gentlemen— I wasted great part of it at Cards.

21. I attended at the Capitol this day at 12 O’Clock, to meet Mr: Giles and the other members of the Committee on the Bill from the House of Representatives, for the punishment of certain Crimes; but when there, Mr: Giles postponed the meeting of the Committee untill Monday; to obtain a copy of the Supreme Court’s Opinion in the cases of Swartwout and Bollman; who had been this morning discharged.— Giles and Willis Alston were very much exasperated at this procedure of the Court; Alston talk’d of impeaching them all; and Giles threatened to lay a motion on the table for a declaratory Amendment of the Constitution, taking away all Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in criminal cases— Adair and Ogden, who were sent to Baltimore, were liberated upon Habeas Corpus issued by Mr: Nicholson, a State Judge— After returning home, I went to Georgetown, and accomplished the business there which I had to do preparatory to my departure.— Evening at home.— I finished at last the copy of my 17th: lecture.

22. Heard Mr: Sayrs of Georgetown— A funeral sermon on the death of a Mrs: Burns— Catherine and Adelaide Johnson went with me— In the afternoon I walk’d with them, nearly to the Capitol. We met Mr: Dana, who walk’d with us, part of the way home— Captain Landais called to see me this morning; and Mr: and Mrs: Quincy were here before dinner— Evening at home.

23. The bill for granting Land to the Chesapeak and Delaware Canal Company, in exchange for their Stock employed almost the whole of this day— I moved that the Bill, and an amendment postponed proposed by Genl: Smith of Maryland, should be postponed, for the purpose of considering a Resolution directing the Secretary of the Treasury to report a general plan for internal improvements of this kind— On this Motion, Mr. Bayard made two long Speeches, which took up the greater part of the day— I spoke about three quarters of an hour; but met no support, except from Genl: Smith, who though opposed to the bill, yet finds himself bound to vote for it, because the particular interest of his State is concerned— The question upon my motion was lost by a vote of 16 to 12; but the question on the passage of the Bill itself to a third reading was postponed untill to-morrow.— It was almost 4. when the Senate adjourned— Evening at Dr: Thornton’s, with a numerous Company— I pass’d it in conversing with various gentlemen, and in listening to the music of the Ladies— Mrs: Thornton, and Miss Murray play’d and sung— Mr: Giles did not offer his threatened motion this day— Eliza Johnson went, and came home with us.

24. The bill in favour of the Canal Company again employed almost the whole of this day— On its being taken up, I found the question would be taken without further observation unless I renewed the attack; which I accordingly did, in a speech of about the same length as that I made yesterday— I replied to most of Mr: Bayard’s arguments in his second Speech of yesterday— There was some degree of weariness manifested when I began—but much more attention was given as I advanced; and the effect was manifest by the time I closed— Mr: Bradley told me in the lobby that I had broken them up— Mr: Moore of Virginia told me at the fire-side that if I would now renew my Motion for postponement untill the next Session, he would vote for it— Mr: Smith of Tennessee said the same to Mr: Bradley— Mr: Worthington of Ohio staggered, and intimated doubts— Mr: White, Mr: Bayard and Mr: Clay were all roused to reply to me; which they all did with some acrimony— But at length I obtained also some assistance, Mr: Hillhouse and Mr: Tracy both supported me; and from two new grounds taken by Mr: Tracy against the Bill, Mr: Pickering and Mr: Giles, began to be doubtful, and to ask postponement untill to-morrow, which however Mr: Bayard refused— I finally renewed the motion for postponement untill the first Monday in December, without my Resolution annexed, and carried the vote 16 to 11.— General Smith of Maryland continued arguing against the bill, and promising to vote for it, and had actually removed one pretty strong objection I had raised, by offering an Amendment, which Bayard was very glad to adopt, and which was carried by a large majority— It was again 4 O’Clock when we adjourned— Evening at home.

25. My proposed Resolution for the appointment of a joint Committee of both houses to enquire and report concerning the Act of the last Session; was taken up, and rejected after a debate, in which Mr: Bradley, Mr: Giles, and Mr: Bayard, and Genl: Smith of Maryland took part against me; while I stood altogether unsupported— At the question, Mr: Turner alone voted with me— Immediately afterwards came on the Bill making appropriations for the Capitol— The Senate’s Committee had reported an Amendment, increasing the appropriation for repairs upon the North-Wing, in which we sit from $25000 to 50,000. against this Amendment I objected, and a debate ensued in consequence of which the amendment was finally rejected by a bare majority 13 to 14. the question was twice taken
taken, for at the first counting the Vice-President mistook the numbers, declared a tie 14 to 14. and decided in favour of the amendment— I desired the question might again be put, for there were only 27 members within the bar—and on counting again it was found the question was lost— The Canal project for the rapids of the Ohio, since the fate of the Bill granting lands to the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, has been modified to a Bill for the appointment of Commissioners to go and ascertain facts upon which a bill was introduced this day, and pass’d to the second reading— Mr: Worthington offered a Resolution for directing the Secretary of the Treasury to report to the next Congress, concerning internal improvements, predicated entirely upon my Resolution, which has not been acted upon, but much less comprehensive. Adjourned about 4. O’Clock— We spent the Evening with a large party at Mr: Madison’s— I avoided Cards; but was amused by various conversation, and Miss Murray’s Music.

26. The Bill making Appropriations for the Capitol was again resumed; and the questions on the Amendments reported by the Quasi-Committee were again taken— A question of order occurr’d—whether the question was again to be put, upon the Amendments reported by the Select Committee; but rejected by the Committee of the whole— The Vice-President did not chuse to decide, but referr’d to the opinion of the Senate themselves— There was much diversity of opinion upon it— I contended that the question could only be put on the amendments reported by the Committee of the whole, as their report only could be before the Senate— After some debate it was agreed to wave the decision on the point of order, and to take the question only on the amendments reported by the Quasi-Committee; and the amendment there rejected, to increase the appropriation for the North Wing, was moved again upon the Bill as in Senate, by Mr: Bradley— After debate it was again rejected, by a bare majority 14 to 15.— The bill for appointing Commissioners to survey the scite for a Canal at the rapids of the Ohio pass’d to the third reading by a large majority, after some opposition.—Adjourn’d about 4. O’Clock.— Mr: Worthington had offered a second Resolution to direct the Secretary of the Treasury to report at the next Session on the practicability of making a Turnpike Road from the North-eastern to the South-Western extremity of the Union— It lays for consideration— After the adjournment I told him that the Resolution I offered two or three days since appeared to me to include the substance of both his and more— Upon my shewing it to him, he said he was pleased with it, and thought it might be so modified, as to supersede the necessity of his two— I left it with him for that purpose— I spent the Evening with Catherine and Adelaide Johnson at Mr: Boyd’s.

27. Met Mr Giles and Genl: Smith of Maryland on the 4. per Cent annuity Bill, and agreed to report its postponement untill the next Session— Which report was made and adopted by the Senate, without debate or division— I forgot to mention yesterday that the bill for repealing the Salt-duties and continuing the Mediterranean fund was lost by the adherence of the House to their Bill, and of the Senate to their Amendments, without a conference.— This day there was a motion in the House of Representatives to recommit the General Appropriation Bill, for the purpose of adding to it three new Sections, being the same as the whole Bill thus lost— This motion was however rejected— Another motion was then made, and finally obtained for a Committee to bring in a Bill to the same effect as that which was lost. The House sat untill 7. in the Evening; and finally adjourned for want of a Quorum— In Senate a Bill for the relief of Stephen Sayre was debated at the third reading; and finally recommitted for Amendment.— The Ohio Canal Bill pass’d; and the yeas and nays were taken upon it at my request. They were 18 and 8.— It had obviously been settled out of doors— In the Evening I went with the Ladies to a Ball, given by Mr: Daniel Clark, the Delegate from the Territory of Orleans; at Stelle’s Hotel— I danced with Mrs: Cutts, and wasted the rest of the time at whist— It was about 2. in the morning when we got home.

28. Met Dr: Mitchill and Mr: Dana, of the library Committee, in the library— Mr: Baldwin and Mr: T. M. Randolph, are both unwell, and were not able to attend— Mr: J. Clay is absent, and being appointed Cashier of a new Bank at Philadelphia, will probably resign his seat in Congress— We could not form a majority of the Committee; but directed an order to be drawn on the Treasurer, for the amount of the annual appropriation, and agreed to meet again Monday morning— A Bill respecting the Louisiana land-titles was debated with various Amendments reported by a Committee; all of which were eventually rejected and the Bill pass’d to the third reading, with a single amendment of a clerical error, which had crept into the engross’d bill as it came from the House of Representatives engross’d— About 4. O’Clock, Mr: Turner of N. Carolina, moved that when the
Senate should adjourn, it might be to meet to-morrow, (Sunday.) which being objected to, he said that his only reason for making the motion was that he expected a Bill would be sent from the House of Representatives, repealing the Salt duties, and continuing the Mediterranean fund, and unless the Senate should meet to-morrow, it would be in the power of any one member to prevent the passage of the Bill, by objecting against its being read more than once in the same day— After some debate, it was agreed to meet again at seven O’Clock this Evening, instead of to-morrow— By invitation of Mr: Pickering, and Mr: Tracy I went and dined with them— At 7. in the Evening we met again, and did little more than make a Quorum— We sat untill about 9. O’Clock— The House also met at 7. And soon took up their Salt-Bill, but there was no prospect of their passing it before Midnight— After several motions in Senate to adjourn had failed, Mr: Maclay renewed the motion for sitting to-morrow; which was debated with some earnestness; but on a call for the yeas and nays the motion was abandoned, and the Senate adjourned untill Monday morning— It rained so heavily that I could not walk home; nor could I procure a Hackney Coach, either at the Capitol or at Stelle’s Hotel— I went into the House of Representatives, where I found them, debating upon the salt-bill— Mr: Wheaton, their Serjeant at Arms, offered to give me a seat in his Carriage, home, if I would wait untill their adjournment— They sat untill half-past one in the Morning; Mr: J. Randolph continually making motions and calling for the yeas and nays, untill he could not obtain one fifth of the members to support him in asking for them— When the question upon the passage of the bill came to be taken there was not a quorum within the bar— Several fruitless attempts were made to call in absent members— At length after counting the members several times, the Speaker appointed Mr: Blount and Mr: Masters, (one of each side, as he said) as tellers; and they then returned seventy one members, which with the Speaker made a Quorum, and the Bill was pass’d— They then immediately adjourned— I rode home with Mr: Wheaton and Mr: Cutts—who both said there was not actually a Quorum when the question was taken— It was about 2. in the morning when I got home.

Day. During the first half of this month like the last— Since then I have abandoned my greek readings in the morning; and have spent the greatest part of my Evenings in Company— The adjournments of the Senate are very late; so that I have no leisure upon my hands, for literary occupation.
